comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: FRAULEIN NOW PROFESSOR.; Rachel Hirsch the First Woman Physician to Gain That Title. Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES. November 16, 1913, Sunday Berlin, Nov. 15 — Unusual honors have been won by Fräulein Rachel Hirsch, who is the first woman physician in Germany to acquire the title of Professor. Fräulein Hirsch, for the past five years, has been the chief assistant of Prof. Kraus, and has conducted a polyclinic for both men and women patients of the university medical clinic of the Berlin Charity Hospital. Fräulein Prof. Dr. Hirsch, which will henceforth be her full title, has not only been active in hospital service but has also done superior research work in the fever and bacteriological fields, also in connection with diabetes and kindred diseases.

comment.author: 17264356@N00
comment._content: "Fräulein Prof. Dr. Hirsch" the Germans always love those long titles.

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: The NY Times notwithstanding, Bain appears to have spelled her name, "Rahel," correctly. She was to be another victim of Nazism, if indirectly: jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/hirsch-rahel

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: Richard Arthur Norton: Thanks for noting the correct spelling.  We'll fix the description next time we update.
